title: Should the religious organization intervene in scientific activities? - Quora

response.answer_text: No. They can fund scientific research that others deem useless if they want. They can employ scientists and organise own research centres - like everyone else can. They should definitely not “intervene” in scientific research in a sense of judging which research is correct and which one isn't.

‘The religious organisation’ - which one? Religious organisations are free to engage in real science if they want to. They can express a view on external scientific developments, and the rest of us are free to ignore them. We are also free to ignore those bodies that engage in pseudoscientific ‘creation science’. What is intolerable is when religious authorities pronounce on the correctness of scientists’ conclusions on non-scientific grounds (“Our book says your findings in biology or cosmology are wrong.”) or the acceptability of their day-to-day work .(“Good morning, brother - we’re from the Ministry of Buggering People About Religiously, and we’ve come to check whether your studies of polymer chemistry are compatible with Islam.”)
